ABSTRACT WESTPHALEN, Gisele de Freitas. Influence of Co/SiC catalyst morphology on Fischer -Tropsch Synthesis . Rio de Janeiro, 2021. - Programa de P√≥s -Gradua√ß√£o em Engenharia de Processos Qu√≠micos e Bioqu√≠micos - Escola de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, 2021.

Silicon carbide (SiC) with different morphologies were synthesized and used as support for cobalt -based c atalysts in Fischer -Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) with the aim of to investigate the effects of textural properties and support morphology on product distribution . Three catalysts synthesized (Co/SiC*, Co/SiCSphere and Co/SiCFiber) with different SiC morphologie s (without defined morphology, sphere and fiber) were evaluated in FTS using a single bed . Catalysts using commercial SiC and SiC without defined morphology were evaluated in a dual bed configuration using mesoporous Y zeolite to optimize gasoline and diesel selectivity. The magnesiothermic reduction reaction (MRR) stands out as a differentiated synthesis method due to the use of magnesium that acts as a temperature reducer that allows obtaining materials with a high specific area, enabling its application as a catalytic suppor t. In this work, SiC was prepared via MRR, which consists of mixing in appropriate proportions a source of silicon, carbon, and magnesium, which is heated between 600 ‚Äì 700 ¬∫C in an inert atmospher e. The change or preservation of the SiC morphology is attributed to silicon precursor . The results showed that the SiC maintained the morphology of spheres and fibers of the synthesized precursor silicas. However, there was a reduction in the specific area of SiC spheres (168 m2 g-1) and SiC fibers (145 m2 g-1) compared to SiC without defined morphology (566 m2 g-1). Among the synthesized catalysts , the Co/SiC* showed the highest activity and formation of liquid hydrocarbons with low methane formation (1.3 %) over 48 h of reaction. The increase in selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons is associated with the catalyst's mesoporosity, facilitating mass transfer inside the pores. Among the dual bed configurations, the Co/SiC + zeolite Y with mesoporou s configuration was the most promising for obtaining liquid fuels with yields above 30 % for kerosene and diesel. The results show that the support morphology affected the textural properties, cobalt dispersion, metal -support interaction, and catalyst acti vity. Keywords: silicon carbide; morphology; cobalt catalyst; Fischer -Tropsch Synthesis.
